This clause in Tenet’s letter does not really concern the question of WMD in Iraq. Nevertheless, the clause directly speaks to one of the Bush administration’s chief justifications for war: Iraq’s alleged links to al-Qaeda. Thus, it is worth considering how Tenet formulated evidence for this claim. One might also consider why CBS ultimately chose not to reproduce this section of Tenet’s letter in its newscast—or even comment on the fact that Tenet had created ready-made political talking points for Congress. However, I have selected this clause primarily to showcase aspects of transitivity analysis.

I don’t mean to suggest that Tenet consciously compared the possessive clause and the existential clause, and then decided on the former. I cite only the alternative existential construction because it nicely shows what Tenet “adds” to the clause when he construes it in the language of possession.

Importantly, while Tenet may have implied that Saddam is dangerous, he never explicitly says this. Arguably, Tenet dismisses the notion that Saddam is dangerous since his letter includes testimony for a “Senior Intelligence” analyst who states that Saddam is unlikely to initiate any attack “in the foreseeable future.” Thus, Rather enhances the negative judgment of Saddam Hussein—transforming the Iraqi leader from “potential threat” to “current threat.” This is the kind of change that a micro-intertextual analysis (discussed below) is well equipped to perceive.

Martin and White’s (2005) discussion of appraisal fits within a wider body of discourse scholarship on stance and evaluation. For other relevant studies, see Biber and Finegan (1989), Hunston and Thompson (2000), Englebretson (2007), and Jaffe (2009).

Martin and White (2005) use the term “entertain” in order to suggest that when speakers use modals and evidentials, they ultimately acknowledge or “entertain” the existence of alternative positions. Thus, when I say, “the dog might run away,” I not only indicate a lack of certainty, but also entertain and open up space for alternative viewpoints (e.g., “the dog might not run away”). Put another way, when we use modals and evidentials we reference the dialogic backdrop for our utterances, indicating that our proposition is just one among a host of competing propositions in the communicative context (p. 105).
A third, extensively rewritten edition of Kress and Van Leeuwen’s (2006) landmark book, Reading Images, is expected soon.
The image was visible for roughly 11 seconds in the segment shown in Appendix B, and it had already been shown for an additional 22 seconds earlier in the newscast.
See Hull and Nelson (2005) and Nelson, Hull, and Roche-Smith (2008) for another approach to video transcription.
See Hagan (2007) for an alternative method of studying visual-verbal collaboration.
Hussein often dressed in Western business attire, and could have been portrayed differently.

Following Fahnestock (1986), rhetoricians have tended to use the term “accommodation” to refer to this process of modifying prior discourse for new audiences. However, I prefer the term “recontextualization,” since it retains the sense that rhetors alter prior discourse, without suggesting that these alterations “meet the needs” of new audiences.
Generally speaking, I followed an inductive approach to coding and writing memos, similar to the grounded theory approaches described in Strauss (1987).
As shown in Appendix A, Tenet initially casts his gaze downward, indicating that he is reading, but he eventually lifts his head and makes sustained “eye contact” with the viewer.

In so doing, CBS likely “buried the lead.” That is, CBS concealed the major discrepancy between Bush and the CIA regarding the likelihood that Saddam Hussein would use his alleged WMD. At the same time, CBS probably accelerated the rush to war in Iraq. By highlighting the supposed danger of Saddam Hussein and obscuring American culpability for provocation, they likely made war seem like the only course of action, that is, the only way to remove an untrustworthy dictator. There are many possible reasons why CBS reported in ways that made war seem desirable and exciting—nationalism, profit motive, and the belief that war was inevitable (Bennett, Lawrence, & Livingston, 2007).

Of course, I could have used other discourse analysis approaches to reach similar conclusions. My point is only that I could not have reached these conclusions using traditional rhetorical techniques.
See Ishizaki & Kaufer (2012) for a discussion of DocuScope, a computational tool for conducting corpus-based rhetorical analysis.

bio.title: Author Biography
bio.p: John Oddo is an assistant professor in the Rhetoric program at Carnegie Mellon University. His research interests include “call-to-arms” rhetoric, including war legitimation in political and media discourse. Currently, he is preparing a monograph that examines the news coverage surrounding Colin Powell’s 2003 UN address.
